data.title: Inconsistent environment and behaviour on macOS

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
# Problem

Various tools don't operate correctly depending on the order and the manner with which VSCode is started on macOS.

Also, persisted state is not restored consistently.

Note: the problem is similar to atom/atom#4126. Although I feel dirty pointing you to a thread pertaining to That Other Editor, the issue is largely the same and some discussion happened over there that one may want to look into for the full effect.

# Cause

Depending the manner in which VSCode is started, a different environment is inherited.

- **launchd event**: inherits launchd mostly blank env, which would mean no shell env vars save from some magic happening and my env vars from a login shell are set (good!)
- **`code` in the terminal**: inherits currently set vars

This applied to when the app is _started_, not when a new window is opened, in which case that window will inherit the current process env (which is normal OS X behaviour).

# Current workaround / Anti-feature

Manually control Code startup each time you want to use it in a specific environment.

Why is it an anti feature? If you want two projects open at the same time but with different environments, you're busted.

Also, long running sessions and _"wait what env was that started with already?"_ (session can also mean the idiomatic "document != app" macOS way: "Visual Studio Code.app is started but no windows are opened").

Also also, frustration quickly sets in when you start it up the wrong way and have to quit and restart halfway through your work and notice your linter does not actually run (manual config does not cut it because 1. it's manual and 2. constantly changing versions means constantly changing path).

# Possible solution

1. sanitize environment upon every launch, with local environment management is bestowed to package implementor (meaning detection of `.git`, `Gemfile`, `.rubocop.yml`, `.gopath`, which they have to do anyway else at least starting via launchd is broken, if not more), not to manual handling by developer.
2. have a clean environment per window (which means per process apparently), which is what Atom chose to do but this approach is [fraught with peril](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/4126#issuecomment-200400013).

# Consequences

- `PATH` & al. is properly set and tools like linters can leverage the env to use chruby/rbenv/whatever.
- Clicking the icon, starting via spotlight, opening a file from Finder, using `open -a "Visual Studio Code"` and using `code foo` on the terminal are all consistent, whatever the order they are executed in.
- Everything is now consistent and we can now rejoice as glittery roses spontaneously bloom out of Bose-Einstein condensates.

# Additional note

On another planet, I don't know if this issue applies to other OSes as well besides macOS. Everything depends on how process management and app/doc/task GUI model is expected to be handled there.

# Final word

All of this really matters daily when you juggle between projects and makes VSCode feel like a brittle product, making angry coworkers throwing rusted nails at me for having pushed VSCode on them. (I realise I pushed the same argument forward on the Atom issue, but hey, we all know deep inside that VSCode is OvbiouslyBetter™, and being thrown sharp objects at twice is doubleplus unfun).

# Details

- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:46:00.226Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.1.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.49|
|Ruby|rebornix|0.10.1|
|slim|sianglim|0.0.1|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open VSCode from Dock/Spotlight
1. toggle developer tools and look at `process.env` in JS console
1. open terminal
1. `export FOO=bar`
1. run `code somewhere` or whatever
1. toggle developer tools in new window and look at `process.env` in console, notice there's no `FOO`
1. quit VSCode completely (for real)
1. run `code somewhere` or whatever
1. toggle developer tools in new window and look at `process.env` in console, notice there's `FOO`
1. open new code window
1. toggle developer tools in new window and look at `process.env` in console, notice there's `FOO`
1. open new terminal tab (that will not have `FOO`)
1. run `code somewhereelse` or whatever
1. toggle developer tools in new window and look at `process.env` in console, notice there's `FOO`

data.title: Telemetry for Settings
data.body:
Just an hypothesis that Following are the two flows which users majorly follow to update a setting

- Find/Copy/Paste : Find the setting in Default settings using Find functionality. Copy and paste it in `Settings.json`. Update it.
- Intelli-sense: Completely use intelli-sense in `Settings.json` to find and update the setting.

Others:
- Navigate through Default settings to find a setting. Copy/Paste/Manually type to update the setting.
- Discover a setting from external source and update it.


We would need some telemetry data to support this hypothesis. This will give some input to improve the UX for managing settings.

data.title: EH debugging: reload window or open project results in two reloads
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insider
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. run Hello World extension from VS Code
2. in EH window reload window (e.g. 'Cmd-R') or open another project

Observe: EH reloads twice

VS Code stable does not show this behaviour.

data.title: Fix to retain and pass args in linux cli
data.body:
The --user-data-dir check routine shifts and removes the args. This edit is to retain the original arguments and pass to executable when finally called.
See issue #15435

data.title: PHP 7 executable not found

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: **1.7.1**
- OS Version: **Windows 10 Pro N** (Version 10.0.14393 Build 14393)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open vscode
2. open .php file
3. even though php 7.0.10 is freshly installed, error about missing executable is shown

Additional info:

1. **wamp server 3.0.6** installed
2. **php 7.0.10** installed (delivered with above)

I've been working with vscode for some time now, and ever since I started, I had php 7 executable set and everything was working. Lately (it might be updates' fault) I got this 'php 7 not installed' error.

Error itself: '**PHP executable not found. Install PHP 7 and add it to your PATH or set the php.executablePath setting**'.

My php-related preferences:

`...
"php.validate.executablePath": "**C:\\wamp64\\bin\\php\\php7.0.10\\php.exe**",

"php.validate.run": "onType",
...`

I tried messing with slashes: '/', '//', '\', '\\' - nothing seems to work.
I also tried to set php 5.6.25 as executable path, but I guess it's php7 only.
I tried to turn off validating php with:
`"php.validate.enable": false`
but that didn't work for me either.
I run php.exe and code.exe as admin.

data.title: Show language service issues in VS Code

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: There were some issues in the past (e.g. #15238 or #13575) that caused the TypeScript service to crash. Unfortunately, VS Code itself did not show any information that the language service has crashed and you have to manually trace the issue. It would be great if VS Code can inform the user that the language service has a sever issue that requires the user to look into it and give a description of the error.

data.title: Persist an extensions manifest file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7035 & https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3884

Persist an extension manifest file `extensions.json` that lists all extensions installed and other relevant data (whether they're disabled?), on launch the list could be checked and automatically install extensions. This would help enable:

- Roaming on Windows #3884
- More logically cache and config files on Linux, also #3884
- Allow extensions or external programs to sync extensions more easily

This is a soft dependency for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3884

data.title: Git commit messages are handled differently to the command line tools
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set a git template with comments in it
2. Make changes to a project using git
3. Make a commit using VS Code with comments in the message

Expected Behaviour:
1. Git commit template is displayed as is
2. Comment lines are stripped when commit is made

Actual Behaviour:
1. Comments are stripped from the template before being displayed
2. Comment lines are included when commit is made

data.title: Command line arguments not working as expected
data.body:
As per, issue #6484 (closed), the command line arguments such as -h, should work with the
current version of VS Code. But does not work as expected in normal ubuntu installation.

Binary being used:

        /usr/bin/code -> /usr/share/code/bin/code

- VSCode Version:

        Version 1.7.1
        Commit 02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44
        Date 2016-11-03T13:46:46.244Z
        Shell 1.3.8
        Renderer 52.0.2743.82
        Node 6.5.0

- OS Version:

       Distributor ID:  Ubuntu
       Description: Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS
       Release: 16.04
       Codename:    xenial

Steps to Reproduce:

    code --user-data-dir=/ws/linux/config/vscode/ /root/.bashrc
    code --user-data-dir=/ws/linux/config/vscode/ --help
    code --user-data-dir=/ws/linux/config/vscode/ /var/logs


None of the above shows any help or open path as expected.

data.title: Move editor to next/previous group keyboard shortcuts do not work on Ubuntu
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.10

Steps to Reproduce:

- Default move editor to next/previous group keyboard shortcuts do not work on Ubuntu.
- At other computer with Windows, where I use the same vscode settings (I sync them with VS Code Settings Sync plugin), these shortcuts work.
- Broken keyboard shortcuts:
```json
{ "key": "ctrl+alt+right",        "command": "workbench.action.moveEditorToNextGroup" },
{ "key": "ctrl+alt+left",         "command": "workbench.action.moveEditorToPreviousGroup" },
```

- If I rebind to `ctrl+left/right` or `alt+left/right` it works so it is probably something with `ctrl+alt` detection
- I am using default English (US) keyboard layout, switching to Czech layout also doesen't help.
- I tested these other "similar" shortcuts and they work as expected:
```json
{ "key": "ctrl+alt+enter",        "command": "editor.action.replaceAll",
                                     "when": "editorFocus && findWidgetVisible" },
{ "key": "shift+alt+right",       "command": "editor.action.smartSelect.grow",
                                     "when": "editorTextFocus" },
{ "key": "shift+alt+left",        "command": "editor.action.smartSelect.shrink",
                                     "when": "editorTextFocus" },
```

data.title: TypeScript multiple errors display problem
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.8.0-insider (fb8939b09460ff9fbd40d39056b54c88d5aad9c8, 2016-11-11T13:12:38.741Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.1.0

---

If the project has multiple errors, for example:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/20247494/9f64822e-a99b-11e6-9afd-f255aa1e537a.png)

and you scroll down a little bit and start working on fixing one by one, then often times the following happens which is pretty disruptive:

1. You click the error to go to it
2. You fix the error
3. You want to click next error in the error list
4. (this step is an issue) - errors will dissapear for some time (will change to 0 ERRORS or some smaller number) and then it will come back to (ORGINIAL_NUMBER_OF_ERRORS-1)
5. Scroll will jump

Seems like maybe vscode could wait a little bit till entire compilation finish and all the errors come back (from tsc or tsserver)

Here are 3 screenshots:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/20247536/b4e76070-a99c-11e6-9b20-cb11d152091a.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/20247539/bc780056-a99c-11e6-9113-fc43767ee30d.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/20247560/18e30480-a99d-11e6-9f06-b0b22c01df29.png)

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 AU

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a tasks.json with the command "C:\\Windows\\sysnative\\bash.exe" and the parameters "-c" and "help"
2. Launch the task

The output now shows Error 0x80070057 with � after each character. Changing "isShellCommand" does nothing.

When executing the same command in cmd it works as expected.

data.title: Extensibility: Typed Commands
data.body:
It seems that vscodes prefererred way of offering API endpoints to extensions is through commands.
For example, vscode.TextEditor's method `hide` is deprecated in favor of the command `workbench.action.closeActiveEditor`. While there might be good reasons to do so, it has the huge disadvantage of loosing types, as there is only the function executeCommand:
`function executeCommand<T>(command: string, ...rest: any[]): Thenable<T>;`

Are there any plans to improve that?

data.title: previewHtml iframe does not use entire space
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a markdown file and open the preview window side by side

## Actual behaviour:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2931520/20245601/00cc2d92-a9a5-11e6-8a16-01043ad2374e.png)
The webview developer tools window shows the following when selecting the top iframe element:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2931520/20245613/4fd939d4-a9a5-11e6-943a-6f7d7f58cc8c.png)

## Expected behaviour:
The space on the right and on the bottom of the preview tab should be used as well. The blue selection should cover the entire white space.

This happens whenever the previewHtml command is used, not only when previewing markdown.

data.title: API: vscode.workspace.findfiles() no longer works with subfolders (since version 1.7.1)
data.body:
- VSCode Version:  1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
**Structure**
```
   D:\Develop\GIT\Test_2 (workspace)
       |- folder
           |- abc.txt
           |- subfolder
              |- test.txt

```
**with the character / it no longer works in subfolder:**
```
  vscode.workspace.findfiles('folder/abc.txt', {.history,.vscode,**/node_modules,typings,out}); // return 1 file ok
  vscode.workspace.findfiles('folder/subfolder/test.txt', {.history,.vscode,**/node_modules,typings,out});  // return 0 file => error it must be 1
```

**with the character \ it works:**
```
  vscode.workspace.findfiles('folder\abc.txt', {.history,.vscode,**/node_modules,typings,out}); // return 1 file ok
  vscode.workspace.findfiles('folder\subfolder\test.txt', {.history,.vscode,**/node_modules,typings,out});  // return 1 file ok
```

Previously, it doesn't work, with character \ so, **what is the correct character to use now (in Windows)** ?

data.title: Format document with conditional compilation in C# will not format code ignored by condition
Format document in a C# file does not use the configured tab-size (while inserting spaces)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:46:00.226Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.1.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|beautify|HookyQR|0.5.4|
|html-css-class-completion|Zignd|1.0.3|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.0.18|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.5.40|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.0.21|
|sass-lint|glen-84|0.0.3|
|Angular2|johnpapa|1.0.2|
|docomment|k--kato|0.0.7|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.4.1|
|mono-debug|ms-vscode|0.11.0|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.2.1|
|sass-indented|robinbentley|1.2.1|
|yo|samverschueren|0.9.2|
|bootstrap-3-snippets|wcwhitehead|0.0.8|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. configure code as follows 
  "editor.tabSize": 2,
  "editor.useTabStops": false,
  "editor.insertSpaces": true,
 
2. Select C# file and choose Format Document. Editor still inserts 4 spaces.
